section.title: about deb
section.para: Most people use aptitude or apt-get to manage their Debian/Ubuntu family of Linux distributions. Both are a front end for dpkg and are themselves a back end for synaptic or other graphical tools.
This is a screenshot of synaptic running on Debian 4.0.

section.title: dpkg -l
section.para: The low level tool to work with .deb packages is dpkgdpkg(8). Here you see how to obtain a list of all installed packages. The ii at the beginning means the package is installed.
section.screen: root@laika:~# dpkg -l | grep gcc-4.2 ii gcc-4.2 4.2.4-1ubuntu3 The GNU C compiler ii gcc-4.2-base 4.2.4-1ubuntu3 The GNU Compiler Collection (base package)

section.title: dpkg
section.para: You could use dpkg -i to install a package and dpkg -r to remove a package, but you'd have to manually keep track of dependencies.

section.title: aptitude
section.para: Most people use aptitudeaptitude(8) for package management on Debian and Ubuntu Systems.
To patch and upgrade all software to the latest version on Debian.
To patch and upgrade all software to the latest version on Ubuntu and Mint.
To install an application with all dependencies.
To search the repositories for applications that contain a certain string in their name or description.
To remove an application and all unused files.

section.title: apt-get
section.para: We could also use apt-getapt-get(8), but aptitude is better at handling dependencies than apt-get. Whenever you see apt-get in a howto, feel free to type aptitude.

section.title: /etc/apt/sources.list
section.para: The resource list for both apt-get and aptitude is located in /etc/apt/sources.list/etc/apt/sources.list. This file contains a list of http or ftp sources where packages for the distribution can be downloaded.
section.screen:
root@barry:~# cat /etc/apt/sources.list
deb http://ftp.be.debian.org/debian/ etch main non-free contrib # deb http://ftp.be.debian.org/debian/ sarge main non-free contrib # deb http://ftp.be.debian.org/debian/ unstable main non-free contrib # deb-src http://ftp.be.debian.org/debian/ etch main non-free contrib
deb http://security.debian.org/ etch/updates main # deb-src http://security.debian.org/ etch/updates main

section.title: alien
section.para: alien is experimental software that converts between rpm and deb package formats (and others).
Below an example of how to use alien to convert an rpm package to a deb package.
section.screen: paul@barry:~$ ls -l netcat* -rw-r--r-- 1 paul paul 123912 2009-06-04 14:58 netcat-0.7.1-1.i386.rpm paul@barry:~$ alien --to-deb netcat-0.7.1-1.i386.rpm netcat_0.7.1-2_i386.deb generated paul@barry:~$ ls -l netcat* -rw-r--r-- 1 paul paul 123912 2009-06-04 14:58 netcat-0.7.1-1.i386.rpm -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 125236 2009-06-04 14:59 netcat_0.7.1-2_i386.deb

para.emphasis: In real life, use the netcat tool provided by your distribution, or use the .deb file from their website.
